main event: A ground observer reported seeing a pinhead of light crossing rapidly from the point of first observation toward the north and disappearing in the area of the Big Dipper in Rome, New York on October 30, 1955.
interesting points: The object was observed for about 1 minute, crossing from an elevation of 75 degrees to 30 degrees and disappearing to the north.
The observer reported no sound, tail, trail or other distinguishable features of the object.
The Air Force investigator, Capt. Richard T. Moody, believed the report was of a star or meteor, though the accuracy of the report was questioned.
The report indicates that PAA and the tower checked for known aircraft on radar, but no other reported traffic or radar returns were noted.
The weather report indicates clear skies with no unusual meteorological conditions that could account for the sighting.
witnesses: One civilian observer, a newscaster and reporter
